entry.title: 几道简单逻辑题
entry.content:
In (1-5), which inferences are correct? Give a proof (using inferencerules of PL and FOL) for each correct inference.

1

\(A\rightarrow C\Rightarrow A\rightarrowB\rightarrow C\)

正确：因为\(A\rightarrowC\)为T，右边恒为T

2

\(\lnot(P\land\lnot Q),\lnot Q \lorR\Rightarrow P\lor R\) \(\Leftrightarrow P\rightarrow Q,Q\rightarrowR\Rightarrow P\lor R\)

错误：若R为F，则Q为F，P为F，左边为T，右边为F，\(T\Rightarrow F\)错误

3

\(\forall x(Ax\rightarrow B),\lnot\forallx(Ax\rightarrow\lnot Cx)\Rightarrow B\)

\[\begin{align}&(1)(UD)\ \ \ \ \forall x(Ax\rightarrow B)\Rightarrow \forallxAx\rightarrow B\\&(2)(UD)\ \ \ \ \lnot\forall x(Ax\rightarrow\lnot Cx)\Rightarrow\lnot(\forall x Ax\rightarrow\forall x \lnot Cx)\\&(3)(MI)\ \ \ \ \Leftrightarrow\lnot(\lnot\forall xAx\lor\forallx\lnot Cx)\\&(4)(DMD)\ \ \ \ \Leftrightarrow\forall xAx\land\lnot\forall x\lnotCx\\&(5)(DMU)\ \ \ \ \Leftrightarrow\forall xAx\land\exists xCx\\&因为(5)为T，所以\forall xAx为T，所以原命题\Leftrightarrow\\&(6)(MP)\forall xAx\rightarrow B, \forall xAx\Rightarrow B,成立\end{align}\]

4

\(A,\lnot\exists x(Bx\land\lnotCx),\lnot\exists x(A\land \lnot Bx)\Rightarrow\exists xCx\)

\[\begin{align}&(1)(DME)\ \ \ \ \lnot\exists x(Bx\land\lnotCx)\Leftrightarrow\forall x(\lnot Bx\lor Cx)\\&(2)(MI)\ \ \ \ \Leftrightarrow\forall x(Bx\rightarrow Cx)\\&(3)(UD)\ \ \ \ \Rightarrow\forall xBx\rightarrow\forall xCx\\&(4)类似(2)(3)\ \ \ \ \lnot\exists x(A\land\lnot Bx)\LeftrightarrowA\rightarrow\forall xBx\\&(5)(MP)\ \ \ \ A,A\rightarrow\forall xBx,\forallxBx\rightarrow\forall xCx\Rightarrow\forall xCx\\&(6)(S3T3)\Rightarrow\exists xCx,成立\end{align}\]

5

\(\forall xAx,\lnot\exists x(\lnot Ax\landBx),Bt\Rightarrow C\)

\[\begin{align}&(DME)\ \ \ \ \lnot\exists x(\lnot Ax\land Bx)\Leftrightarrow\forallx(Bx\rightarrow Ax)\\&所以左式\Leftrightarrow\forall xAx, \forall x(Bx\rightarrowAx),Bt\\&取x=t,左式为T,而C可能为F,所以T\Rightarrow F不成立\\&若C恒为T，则无论左式是T还是F，命题必然恒成立\end{align}\]

补充

Material Implication (MI): \(P\rightarrowQ\Leftrightarrow \lnot P\lor Q\)

PQ\(P\rightarrow Q\)
TTT
TFF
FTT
FFT

\[\begin{align}\forall x(Ax\lor\lnot Bx)\\\Leftrightarrow \forall x(\lnot Ax\rightarrow \lnot Bx)\\\textcolor{red}{\Rightarrow} \forall x\lnot Ax\rightarrow\forall x\lnotBx\\\Leftrightarrow\exists xBx\rightarrow\exists xAx\ \ \ \ (*)\\\\\forall x(\lnot Bx\lor Ax)\\\Leftrightarrow\forall x(Bx\rightarrow Ax)\\\textcolor{red}{\Rightarrow}\forall xBx\rightarrow\forall xAx\\\Leftrightarrow\lnot\forall xAx\rightarrow\lnot\forall xBx\\\Leftrightarrow\forall xBx\rightarrow\forall xAx\ \ \ \ (**)\end{align}\]

entry.title: 2023.09.23一盒红柚
entry.content:
前天星期四晚上，我在校外跑步，给自己买了一盒红柚，15元。柚子很好吃，我感到很幸福。

水果店在复兴中路上。当时我刚好跑完2km，想找辆自行车骑回去。沿着人行道随便乱走，路过这家水果店。有一个先生站在门口，边抽烟边隔着门帘和店主聊天。我低着头从他身边走过，一眼就看到了门口摆着的塑料盒子装的柚子。柚子都是剥好的，看着很诱人。要是是完整的，或许也不会激起我的冲动，但是剥好的柚子就不一样了，让人不禁想象下一刻就能放进嘴里品尝，老板真的很会做生意。

通常情况下，我是不会停下我的脚步的。这次也是如此，匆匆走了过去。但是走了几步路，我就在想为什么不买一盒尝尝呢？好久没有吃水果了，我也好想吃水果啊。对于吃，我向来是没有太多欲望的。这几天牙又疼，张大嘴巴都有些难受，本也想一如既往压制住自己的馋意，但是我想起了之前和jljj的聊天。她是一个非常好的人，认为活着的意义在于吃好吃的，我感觉她的观点也有一定道理，吃好吃的确实能让人感到愉悦。我又想柚子是水果，可以补充维生素，是有利健康的，所以完全没理由不买。于是我又往回走去。

我放慢了脚步。抽烟的人仍然在和店主对话，店主手里正在用刀削一个石榴。我看到门口写着“白柚10元/盒”“红柚15元/盒”，犹豫了，继续往前走去。拿出手机，我给爸妈发了个信息。一方面，我想告知他们准备买一盒柚子；另一方面，我生怕买的质量不好，想问问他们现在是不是柚子上市的日子。

踯躅不前了一会，我看到那个抽烟的先生发现了我，估计是感觉我鬼鬼祟祟的，有些莫名。我问自己在纠结什么，下定决心直接走上前去，莽进了水果店的门，和店主说我想要买一盒柚子。吸烟者中断了和店主的交谈，水果店里顿时安静。“红的十五，白的十块。”我付了钱，说：“拿红的吧。”店主走到门口说：“好嘞，自己挑。”我也判断不出好坏多少，就直接拿了最顺手的一盒。刚准备走，他叫住我，帮我把柚子装进一个塑料袋里。

我拎着袋子离开了，世界又热闹了起来。走在路上，看着粉里透红的柚子，我很开心，因为这好像是第一次因为自己想吃而给自己买了水果，勤快一点，多吃点水果也挺好。我感觉自己成长了，因为这是第一次因为自己想吃而给自己买了水果。

买完柚子后也不早了，共享单车稀少，一时半会找不到。我端着盒子走在人行道上，很想吃一口柚子，于是就吃了一口。非常好吃，又想把柚子带回宿舍吃，但是就一点点柚子，带回去似乎不方便也没必要。而且我如果带回了宿舍，必然会选择分给三位舍友，但只买了少数，4个人分略显寒碜，不大好看。

所以我干脆边走边吃柚子，边找共享单车。途中经过别的水果店，也看到有卖柚子的，红柚20元一包，但是很多，大概有4-5瓣的样子。我不知道自己究竟是赚了还是亏了。手机里爸妈还在给我提供解决牙疼的方法，让我买点罐头梨吃，说是去火的，我说回头再买吧，其实是我懒了。

总之，在那一刻的柚子真的很好吃，虽然它还是正常的味道，并没有形成什么美味。今天我的牙也好的差不多了，虽然它还是有点疼，得去治疗。我感到很幸福。

entry.title: 中级微观经济学-课程笔记
entry.content:
本笔记整理自安泰经济与管理学院2023年秋季学期课程ECON2404-07中级微观经济学，授课人是XiZhi "RC“ Lim老师。

Lecture 1 A first look

Efficiency

An economist's objective

Allocation

An arrangement of who gets what

A "good" allocation

Pareto efficiency 帕累托有效

An allocation is PE if there is no otherfeasible allocation that makes someone better off and no oneworse off.

Kaldor-Hicksefficiency 卡尔多-希克斯有效

拍累托最优和功利主义有区别吗?- 知乎 (zhihu.com)

卡尔多改进，是指为了让输家接受再分配，再分配的赢家愿意付给输家的钱，高于输家愿意接受的心理价位；希克斯改进，是指为了让赢家放弃再分配，输家愿意付给赢家的钱，低于赢家的心理价位。

但是，这个效率有问题(Tibor Scitovsky, 1951) - Antisymmetric反对称性：存在这样的情况，分配方案A是分配方案B的卡尔多-希克斯改进，但同时方案B也是分配方案A的卡尔多-希克斯改进。- Intransitive不可传递性：存在这样的情况，分配方案A是分配方案B的卡尔多-希克斯改进，分配方案B是分配方案C的卡尔多-希克斯改进，但是分配方案C又是分配方案A的卡尔多-希克斯改进。

Case 0

Ann likes banana \(\succ\) apple andBob likes apple \(\succ\) banana

  • Allocation: Ann has 1 apple & 1 banana, Bob has nothing
    • Q: Is it Pareto-efficient？
      • A: Probably yes! 还需比较apple, banana vs nothing
Case 1

Ann's wealth is x=(1 house, 1 car, $20w, 1 wife) Bob's wealth isy=($500, 1 cat, 5000 bananas)

  • Preference 1: Ann prefers \(x+1\ banana\-\$2\) to \(x\), Bob prefers\(y\ -1\ banana\ +\$2\) to \(y\)
    • Q: Is \((x,y)\) PE?
      • A: If trade is feasible, no.
    • Q: Is \((x+1\ banana\ -\$2, y-1\ banana\+\$2)\) PE?
      • Not necessarily.
Summary
  • 两个两个分配慢慢比较，不要想当然用传递性，小心负效用和零效用
  • 考虑交易成本

Resource Allocation

\(N\) producers, \(M\) machines, \(\$X\) cash, transferable. Producer \(i\) can turn (at most) one machine into\(\$x_i\).

Theorem 1:

An allocation is PE if and only if \(M\) producers with the highest \(x_i\) ’s receive the machines

: I think the principle is to give each machine to the producerwhom can turn it to the highest revenue.

Market

  • Pareto-efficiency was not the intention of market participants; theysimply did what is best for them.
  • So, is "Equilibrium \(\Rightarrow\)Pareto-efficiency" a coincidence?
  • More generally (no price market and market-maker), what is an"equilibrium" and its relationship to PE?

:帕累托有效是必然的，是自发性的最终结果

Other than efficiency

If a free market is so good, why governmentinterferes?

我来鹅城只办三件事，公平，公平，还是TMD公平！

Lecture 2 Preference andUtility

  • 效用存在吗？为什么能说人有效用？还能用数学表达式刻画？
  • 偏好存在是合理的

Preference Relations

Binary relations

Let \(\succcurlyeq\) be a binaryrelation 二元关系 over \(X\) Let's call(i.e., def) this binary relation a preference relation 偏好关系 - Ifapple \(\succcurlyeq\) orange, we say"apple weakly preferred to orange" - Given \(\succcurlyeq\) , we can define \(\succ\) and \(\sim\) in the following way: - Indifference无差异 - \(x\sim y\) : when \(x\succcurlyeq y\) and \(y \succcurlyeq x\) - Strict preference严格偏好 - \(x \succ y\) : when \(x \succcurlyeq y\) and \(\lnot (y\succcurlyeq x)\)

Definition:

\(\succcurlyeq\) isreflexive 自反性 if \(x\succcurlyeq x\) for all \(x\in X\) \(\succcurlyeq\) is complete完备性 if for all \(x,y\inX\), either \(x\succcurlyeq y\)or \(y\succcurlyeq x\) or both.：完备性包含了自反性

  • Cal has preference \(\succcurlyeq =\emptyset\) (nothing is weakly preferred to anything)
    • neither reflexive nor complete
Definition:

\(\succcurlyeq\) istransitive 传递性 if \(x\succcurlyeq y\) and \(y\succcurlyeq z\) implies \(x\succcurlyeq z\)

  • Ellen has preference \(x\succcurlyeqy,y\succcurlyeq z, z\succ x\)
    • not transitive

Rationality

\(\succcurlyeq\) is rational if itis complete and transitive

If not, ...

  • That is, we understand people are different and may have differentpreference, but they "should" obey some basic properties
  • Hence, complete and transitive are often called axioms 公理

Utility

Utility Representation

Theorem 1a

Suppose \(X\) is finite.If \(\succcurlyeq\) iscomplete and transitive, then there exists a function\(U:X\rightarrow \mathbb{R}\) such that\(x\succcurlyeq y\Leftrightarrow U(x)\geqU(y)\).

That's called utility representation 效用表示

Theorem 1b

Suppose \(X\) is finite.If there exists a function \(U:X\rightarrow \mathbb{R}\) such that \(x\succcurlyeq y\Leftrightarrow U(x)\geqU(y)\), then \(\succcurlyeq\) is complete andtransitive.

Utility maximization

Theorem 2

If \(U:X\rightarrow \mathbb R\) is autility representation of \(\succcurlyeq\), then for all \(A\subseteq X\), \[\{x\in A:x\succcurlyeq y\ \forall\ y\in A\}\equiv \arg\max_{x\in A}U(x)\]

Utility representationtheorem

  • Rational preference is sufficient (1a) and necessary (1b) forutility representation.
  • \(\Rightarrow\) The set ofpreference relations (people) that are rational is exactly the set thathave utility representations.
  • \(\Longrightarrow\) If you believepeople have complete and transitive preference relations, then youshould accept the use of utility functions to represent thesepeople.
  • \(\Longrightarrow\) If you furtherbelieve people maximize their preference, then you should accept arepresentation of utility maximization.

:不是所有理性的偏好都可以被效用函数表示，可数集总成立，不可数凸集要连续性见下文

Ordinal vs Cardinal

Theorem 3

Fix \(\succcurlyeq\) . Suppose \(U:X\rightarrow \mathbb R\) represents \(\succcurlyeq\). \(V:X\rightarrow \mathbb R\) also represents\(\succcurlyeq\) if and only if \(V=f\circ U\) for some strictly increasingfunction \(f:\mathbb R\rightarrow \mathbbR\).

Why? - \(\succcurlyeq\) is a rankingof alternatives/bundles in \(X\) -Since \(U\) only conveys as muchinformation as \(\succcurlyeq\), itcannot convey how much better or worse is \(x\) relative to \(y\).

  • Q: The same preference can be represented bydifferent utility functions, what’s problematic about this?
  • A1: Welfare
  • A2: Marginal utility

Infinite X

理性偏好+Complete+Transitive+Continuity\(\Rightarrow\)效用表示

选择理论1——解构理性：偏好，选择，效用- 知乎 (zhihu.com)

连续性的意思就是说，如果 \(y\)比 \(x\) 好，那么任意离 \(y\) 足够近的东西都比离 \(x\) 足够近的东西好。

  • Complete and transitive are "meaningful"
  • Continuity is "technical"
Lexicographic preferences

  • A girl prefers taller men to short men (regardless of weight),and if two men have the same height, then she prefers the heavier to thelighter.

  • 理性但不连续

  • 无效用表示

Convex preferences

Definition

\(\succcurlyeq\) is - Convex - if\(x\succcurlyeq y\Rightarrow \alphax+(1-\alpha)y\succcurlyeq y\ \forall\ \alpha\in[0,1]\) - Strictlyconvex 严格凸 - if \(x\succcurlyeqy\Rightarrow \alpha x+(1-\alpha)y\succ y\ \forall\ y\neq x\ \&\\alpha\in(0,1)\)

Some kind of preference for balanced variety.

Theorem 4

Lagrange

\[\begin{align}&\max_{x_1,\cdots,x_n}U(x_1,\cdots,x_n)\\&s.t.\ x_1p_1+\cdots+x_np_n=m\end{align}\] Turns to \[\begin{align}&\max_{x_1,\cdots,x_n,\lambda}U(x_1,\cdots,x_n)-\lambdaf(x_1,\cdots,x_n)\\&s.t.\ f(x_1,\cdots,x_n)=x_1p_1+\cdots+x_np_n-m\end{align}\] 1. \(\lambda\) issometimes called the shadow price. It represents the marginal utility ofincome at optimal consumption (as you will see). 2. Therefore, thismethod exploits the a binding budget constraint to bring the trade-offbetween choice variables \(x_1,\cdots,x_n\) into the maximizationproblem by linking them to \(\lambda\).

  • FOCs:
    • \(x_1p_1+\cdots+x_np_n=m\)
    • \(\cfrac{MU_i}{p_i}=\lambda=\cfrac{MU_j}{p_j}\RightarrowMRS_{ji}=-\cfrac{p_i}{p_j}\) for all \(i,j\)

Karush-Kuhn-Tucker (KKT条件)

A method to solve optimization problem for which constraints hold,but need not bind. ### Some rule of thumb Remember thatnecessary conditions may not be sufficient. 1. If preference iswell-behaved, check if any \(x^*\geq0\) satisfies (1)+(2), they are the solutions. If not, checkcorner bundles. 2. If preference is monotonic, check if any \(x^*\geq 0\) satisfies (1)+(2), compareutility among them and with corner bundles. If not,check corner bundles. 3. Useful fact: If \(MU_i(\pmb x)\rightarrow \infty\) when \(x_i\rightarrow 0\) (Inada condition稻田条件), then there is no solution such that \(x_i=0\) (no corner solutions 边角解).

Lecture 5 Revealed Preference1

Preference vs Choice

Suppose we observe, from one individual, a dataset of choice sets andchoices - When are they consistent with themaximization of some preference？ - Throughout, we focus on the casewithout indifference

Primitive

  • "\(c(B)=x\)" means choosing \(x\) from the choice set \(B\subset X\)
  • "\(c(\{x,y,z\})=x\)" means choosing\(x\) from \(x,y,z\)
  • Each is a decision
  • A dataset is a collection of decisions made by an individual

Example #3

A dataset: \(c(\{x,y\})=x,c(\{y,z\})=y,c(\{x,z\})=z\) -Q1: Could he be maximizing a preference? - Yes. - Q2: Could he bemaximizing a rational preference? - No.

The emphasis

  • We start with a dataset of choices (of one individual)
  • And then ask if it could come from a rational preference

Choices are real, preferences are theories (stories) that attempt toexplain something real. - Some choices could not havecome from a rational preference - So choices that could comefrom a rational preference will need to satisfy some properties

WARP and SARP显示偏好弱（强）公理

Primitive

  • \(X\): a set of alternatives
  • \(A\): a choice set, nonemptysubset of \(X\)
  • \(\mathcal A\): a collection ofchoice sets
  • \(c: \mathcal A\rightarrow X\) suchthat \(c(A)\in A\): a choice function /dataset

Model

Definition: \(c\) is rationalized理性化 by a (strict) preference relation \(\succ\) if \[c(A)\equiv\{x\in A: x\succ y\ for\ all\ y\in A\backslash\{x\}\}\ for\all\ A\] - Q1: Is there a \(c\)that can be rationalized by a \(\succ\), but not by any rational \(\succ\)? - \(c(\{x,y,z_1\})=x,c(\{x,y,z_2\})=y\). It'snot rational. - Q2: Is there a \(c\)that cannot be rationalized by any \(\succ\)? - \(c(\{x,y,z\})=x,c(\{x,y\})=y\)

可理性化的定义

We say \(C\) is rationalizable ifit satisfies:
(Condition \(\alpha\)​​​): If \(x\in A\subset B\)​​ and \(x\in C(B)\)​​, then \(x\in C(A)\)​​​.
(Condition \(\beta\)): If \(x,y\in C(A)\), \(A\subset B\) and \(y\in C(B)\), then \(x\in C(B)\).

  • Sen 对于 Condition \(\alpha\) 的解释:如果某场世界级比赛的冠军是一个巴基斯坦人，那么这个人也是巴基斯坦的冠军。
  • Sen 对于 Condition \(\beta\) 的解释:如果某场世界级比赛的冠军是（几个）巴基斯坦人，那么所有这场比赛中的巴基斯坦人都是世界冠军。

Preference Revelation

Definition: If \(c(A)=x\) and \(y\in A\backslash\{x\}\),let \(xR_Dy\).

  • "\(x\) is directly revealedpreferred 直接显示偏好 to \(y\)"
  • \(R_D\) is derived from choicedata
  • Therefore, it does not (yet) guarantee a rational preference
Theorem 1

If \(c\) isrationalized by a rational \(\succ\) ,then \(xR_Dy\Rightarrow\neg(yR_Dx)\).

WeakAxiom of Revealed Preferences (WARP) 显示偏好弱公理

\[\text{If}\ xR_Dy,\ \text{then not}\yR_Dx\] - A property of a dataset - If a dataset violates WARP,then it cannot come from the maximization of a rational preference.

但是，由于有Example#3这种偏好，满足WARP，但仍不是理性的。所以还需要更多。

Indirect PreferenceRevelation

Definition: \[\text{If}\ xR_Dx\\text{and}\ zR_Dy,\ \text{then let}\ xR_Iy\]

  • "\(x\) indirectly is revealedpreferred 间接显示偏好 to \(y\)"
  • We (may) never see \(x\) chosen inthe presence of \(y\)
    • But we see \(x\) chosen over \(z\) and \(z\) chosen over \(y\)
    • So we conclude, indirectly, that the 𝑥 is preferred to 𝑦
Theorem 2

If \(c\) isrationalized by a rational \(\succ\),then \(xR_Dy\) or\(xR_Iy\Rightarrow\neg(yR_Dx)\) and\(\neg(yR_Ix)\).

StrongAxiom of Revealed Preferences (SARP) 显示偏好强公理

\[\text{If}\ xR_Dy\ \text{or}\ xR_Iy,\\text{then neither}\ yR_Dx\ \text{nor}\ yR_Ix\] - Again, it is aproperty of a dataset

Back to Example#3
  1. If a guy has \(c(\{x,y\})=x,c(\{y,z\})=y,c(\{x,z\})=z\)
  2. This gives \(xR_Dy,yR_Dz\), and\(zR_Dx\)
  3. And therefore WARP is satisfied
  4. But since \(xR_Dy\) and \(yR_Dz\), we set \(xR_Iz\)
  5. But then \(zR_Ix\) and \(xR_Iz\), so SARP isfalsified
  • Q1: Can a dataset satisfy WARP but not SARP?
    • Yes.
  • Q2: Can a dataset satisfy SARP but not WARP?
    • No.
  • Found two necessary conditions 必要条件
  • A dataset come from rational preference must satisfies SARP &WARP

Representation Theorem表示定理

Theorem 3

An exhaustive dataset of choices can be rationalized by arational preference relation if and only if itsatisfies WARP. exhaustive: Every (nonempty) \(A\subset X\) is in \(\mathcal A\)

  • "Only if" part is Theorem 1
  • Proof (If)
    1. Construction: Given \(c\), let\(x\succ y\) if there exists \(A\) such that \(c(A)=x\)
    2. Show complete: From \(A=\{x\}\) ,we have \(x\succ x\). From \(A=\{x,y\}\), we have \(x\succ y\) or \(y\succ x\).
    3. Show transitive: Knowing \(\succ\)is complete, suppose for contradiction \(x\succ y\), \(y\succ z\), and \(z\succ x\). Consider \(A^*=\{x,y,z\}\), which is in \(\mathcal A\) since it is exhaustive.Suppose WLOG \(c(A^*)=x\), then \(xR_Dz\), which contradicts WARP.
    4. Show \(\succ\) rationalizes \(c\): Consider \(A\in\mathcal A\). By construction, \(c(A)\succ y\) for all \(y\in A\backslash\{c(A)\}\), so we just needto make sure there is no \(y\inA\backslash\{c(A)\}\) such that \(y\succ z\) for all \(z\in A\backslash\{y\}\) . Suppose forcontradiction there is, then in particular we have \(y\succ c(A)\) , which means there is achoice set \(B\) such that \(c(B)=y\) and \(c(A)\in B\). But this implies \(yR_Dc(A)\) , which contradicts WARP.
  • If an exhaustive dataset of choices satisfies WARP, then it is as-ifthe individual makes decision by maximizing a rational preference.
  • WARP is sufficient and necessary for rationalization

Theorem 4

A dataset of choices can be rationalized by a rational preferencerelation if and only if it satisfies SARP.

  • "Only if" part is Theorem 2
  • The proof is more involved.
    1. We build \(R_D\) and \(R_I\) using the dataset of choices.
    2. We write \(xR_Cy\) if either \(xR_Dy\) or \(xR_Iy\) or both.
    3. Note that at this point, \(R_C\) isneither guaranteed complete nor guaranteedtransitive.
    4. By SARP, \(R_C\) isacyclic (if \(x_1R_Cx_2,x_2R_Cx_3\cdots,x_{n-1}R_Cx_n\)where \(x_i\neq x_j\) , then not \(x_nR_Cx_1\)).
    5. Then, it is well-known that a transitive closure of \(R_C\) exists, denoted by \(R_C^\prime\) .
    6. Now we arbitrarily "join" the chains in \(R_C^\prime\) and let \(\succ\) be the output, which is completeand transitive.
    7. Finally, we need to show that \(\succ\) rationalizes the dataset of choices(for example, by arguments of contradictions).

Comments

  • Theorem 3 (and 4) is a watered-down version of the “2nd Theorem” ina field in economics called decision theory
  • It captures rationalizable choice if and only if rationalpreference.
  • The “1st Theorem” is “utility representation if and only if rationalpreference”, which you saw in Lecture 2
  • Together, they link choice and utility, fact and intuitions,falsifiable and thought-exercise, reality andmodels

Lecture 6 Revealed Preference2

Back to the Consumer Problem

Lecture 5 Theorem 4

A dataset of choices \(c:\mathcalA\rightarrow X\) can be rationalized by a rational preferencerelation if and only if it satisfies SARP.

  • This theorem works for arbitrary choice sets and arbitrary choices,including the consumer problem
  • But, we cannot observe all choice sets in a consumer problem.
  • So how can we define \(R_D\) and\(R_I\) ?

Inferred Budget

  • When the consumer chooses \(\pmbx\) at \(\pmb p\), the set \(\{\pmb z:\pmb z\pmb p\leq\pmb x\pmb p\}\)contains affordable bundles
  • So, we conclude \(\pmb xR_D\pmbx^\prime\) for all \(\pmbx^\prime\in\{\pmb z:\pmb z\pmb p\leq\pmb x\pmb p\}\backslash\{\pmbx\}\)

Assumptions

Additional assumptions can help us better infer preference,especially suitable when these assumptions make sense.

With loss, we focus on underlying preferences that are… 1. Strictlyconvex : for unique solution 2. Monotonic : so that choices must be justaffordable

Example choice gives \(R_D\)

1.\(\pmb xR_D\pmb y\) 2. \(\pmb xR_D\pmb z\) 3. Neither \(\pmb xR_D\pmb a\) nor \(\pmb aR_D\pmb x\) 4. \(\pmb bR_D\pmb x\)

Example: from \(R_D\) to \(R_I\)

\(\pmb x^* R_D\pmb y^*\) and \(\pmb y^*R_D\pmb z\), so \(\pmb x^*R_I\pmb z\)

"Qualifying dataset"

Given a finite collection of choice-price pairs\((\pmb x,\pmb p)\) ,construct a qualifying dataset: 1. Add to every datapoint the income \(m:=\pmb x\pmb p\),so that each data point becomes \((\pmb x,\pmbp,m)\) 2. Check no two datapoints \((\pmb x,\pmb p,m)\) and \((\pmb x^\prime,\pmb p^\prime, m^\prime)\)are such that \(\pmb p=\pmb p^\prime\)and \(m=m^\prime\) but \(\pmb x\neq\pmb x^\prime\)

Definitions: 1. Given \(U,\pmb x^*(\pmbp,m)\) denotes the solution to \(\displaystyle\max_{\pmb x} U(\pmb x)\)subject to \(\pmb x\pmb p\leq m\). 2. A\(WB-U\) is a utility function thatrepresents well-behaved preference.

Theorem 1

Given a qualifying dataset, the following are equivalent: 1. Thedataset satisfies SARP. 2. There exists a \(U\) such that if \((\pmb x,\pmb p,m)\) is in the dataset, then\(\pmb x=\pmb x^*(\pmb p,m)\). 3. Thereexists a \(WB-U\) such that if \((\pmb x,\pmb p,m)\) is in the dataset, then\(\pmb x=\pmb x^*(\pmb p,m)\).

即显示偏好需要良性偏好 ##### Picture proof

Lecture 7 Demand

Utility maximization of budgetconstrained individuals gives \[x_1^*(p_1,\bar p_2,\cdots,\bar p_N,\barm)=x_1\]

(Ordinary) Demand Functions

Ordinary demand

\[x_1^*(p_1,\bar p_2,\cdots,\bar p_N,\barm)=x_1\] Call it an ordinary (Marshallian) demand function

Cobb-Douglas Example

Consumer maximizes \(U(x_1,x_2)=x_1^ax_2^b\) subject to budgetconstraint \(\pmb x\pmb p\leq m\) -Optimal consumption (Lecture 4): \[\pmbx^*(p_1,p_2,m)=\left(\cfrac{a}{(a+b)}\cfrac{m}{p_1},\cfrac{b}{(a+b)}\cfrac{m}{p_2}\right)\]- Ordinary demand functions: \[x_1^*(p_1,\barp_2,\bar m)=\cfrac{a}{(a+b)}\cfrac{\bar m}{p_1},\ \ \ \ x_2^*(\barp_1,p_2,\bar m)=\cfrac{b}{(a+b)}\cfrac{\bar m}{p_2}\]

Own-price Changes

A general approach

  • “Changes of (optimal) consumption of \(x_i\) when \(p_i\) changes, holding \(m\) and other prices constant.”

Price offer curve and Demandcurve

Example 1

Cobb-Douglas: \[\pmbx^*(p_1,p_2,m)=\left(\cfrac{a}{(a+b)}\cfrac{m}{p_1},\cfrac{b}{(a+b)}\cfrac{m}{p_2}\right)\]

Example 2

Perfect complements: \(U(x_1,x_2)=\min\{x_1,x_2\}\) \[\pmbx^*(p_1,p_2,m)=\left(\cfrac{m}{p_2+p_1},\cfrac{m}{p_2+p_1}\right)\]

Example 3

Perfect substitutes: \(U(x_1,x_2)=x_1+x_2\) \[\pmb x^*(p_1,p_2,m)=\begin{cases}\left(0,\cfrac{m}{p_2}\right)\ \ \ \ &p_1>p_2\\\left(\cfrac{\beta m}{p_1},\cfrac{(1-\beta) m}{p_2}\right)\ \ \ \&p_1=p_2\\\left(\cfrac{m}{p_1},0\right)\ \ \ \ &p_1<p_2\end{cases}\]

Cross-price Changes

  • If \(p_j\uparrow\) leads to \(x_i\uparrow\), we call \(i\) a gross substitute 总替代品 for \(j\)
  • If \(p_j\uparrow\) leads to \(x_i\downarrow\), we call \(i\) a gross complement 总互补品 for \(j\)

Income Changes

A general approach

  • "Changes of (optimal) consumption of \(x_i\) when \(m\) changes, holding prices constant."

Income offer curve and EngelCurve

Example 1

Cobb-Douglas \[\pmbx^*(p_1,p_2,m)=\left(\cfrac{a}{(a+b)}\cfrac{m}{p_1},\cfrac{b}{(a+b)}\cfrac{m}{p_2}\right)\]- Engel curves: \[\begin{align}m=\cfrac{(a+b)p_1}{a}x_1\\m=\cfrac{(a+b)p_2}{b}x_2\end{align}\]

Types of Commodity

Income Effects

Definitions: when \(m\)increases… 1. Normal good 正常商品 if \(x_i^*(\pmb p,m)\) always increases - Engelcurve is positively sloped 2. Inferior good 低档商品 if \(x_i^*(\pmb p,m)\) sometimes decreases -Engel curve is sometimes negatively sloped

Normal vs Inferior
  • Q: Suppose \(U\) representsmonotonic + convex preference (\(U\) isstrictly increasing in all goods), is it possible that a good isinferior?
  • Yes, it is.
Luxury and Necessity(都属于正常商品)

Definitions: when \(m\)increases… 1. Luxury good 奢侈品 if \(x_i^*(\pmb p, m)\) increases by a greaterproportion 2. Necessity 必需品 if \(x_i^*(\pmbp,m)\) increases by a smaller proportion (Income elasticity ofdemand \(\gtrless\) 1)

Homothetic Preference

Definitions: when \(m\) increases…1. Homothetic preference if \(\foralli,x_i^*(\pmb p,m)\) increases by the same proportion

Own Price Effects

Definitions: When \(p_i\) increases…1. Ordinary good 普通商品 if \(x_i^*(\pmbp,m)\) always decreases 2. Giffen good 吉芬商品 if \(x_i^*(\pmb p,m)\) sometimes increases

Glossary

Jensen & Miller (2008)

Giffen behavior in China

Lecture 8 SlutskyDecomposition

A composition

  • Before price changes: \(x_1^0\)(initial consumption)
  • After price changes: \(x_1^1\) (newconsumption)

Part of \(x_1^1-x_1^0\) is due tosubstitution effect (SE), the rest due to income effect (IE)

Intermediate demand

Find an intermediate demand \(x_1^S\) such that, later by definition,Substitution effect: \(SE_1=x_1^S-x_1^0\) Income effect: \(IE_1=x_1^1-x_1^S\) Total effect: \(SE_1+IE_1=x_1^1-x_1^0\)

Slutsky's Decomposition

What could \(x_1^S\) be?

\[\begin{align}SE_1=x_1^S-x_1^0\\IE_1=x_1^!-x_1^S\end{align}\] - The portion \(x_1^0\rightarrow x_1^S\) captures changesnot due to income

Real income

Even though nominal income \(m\)never changes, changes in \(p_1\)caused an increase in real income, because the set of bundles we canafford expanded.

Affordability of originalbundle

  • Initial: \(\pmb p=(p_1,p_2)\)
  • New: \(\pmb p^\prime=(p_1^\prime, p_2)\ \\ \ p_1^\prime<p_1\) The cost oforiginal bundle at new prices is \[x_1^*(p_1,p_2,m)p_1^\prime+x_2^*(p_1,p_2,m)p_2=m^\prime\]
  • Changes in price to \(\pmbp^\prime\) paired with changes in income to \(m^\prime\), so that original bundle is justaffordable, as if your real income has not changed

Substitution Effect

Now solve the consumer problem under this income and new prices, for\[\pmb x^S:=\pmbx^*(p_1^\prime,p_2,m^\prime)\] Slutsky'ssubstitution effect for good 1: \[SE_1=x_1^S-x_1^0\] Driven by price (ratio)changes, holding real income fixed. #### IncomeEffect Solve the consumer problem under true income and new prices, for\[\pmb x^1:=\pmbx^*(p_1^\prime,p_2,m)\] Slutsky'sincome effect for good 1: \[IE_1=x_1^1-x_1^S\]

Effects of \(p_1\) on \(x_2\)

In this case, when \(p_1\)decreases, - Substitution effect causes \(x_2\) to decrease - Income effect causes\(x_2\) to increase

A useful imagination

Slutsky introduced a concept that allows us to separateincome effect and substitution effect underprice changes

  • But \(\pmb x^S\) is a concept; itis not observable, not verifiable, not falsifiable, it just doesn’texist in the real world
  • It lives in human’s capacity for knowledge and imagination, acceptedbecause it appears reasonable
  • And it is useful---the ultimate goal of every model---in helping usthink about what drives behavior

Sign of Substitution Effect

  • (\(\pmb x^0\pmb p=m\))
  • When \(p_1\) decreases, where is\(\pmb x^S\)?
  • If it is in the green: \(p_1\downarrow\Rightarrow SE_1\geq0\)
  • Is it always in the green?

Theorem 1

If preference is monotonic, \(\pmbx^S\in\pmb x^*(p_1^\prime,p_2,m^\prime)\Rightarrow\pmb x^S\inGreen\) 一句话，红色被\(\pmbx^0\) 显示偏好了，好像秒了 ##### Proof Monotonic preferenceimplies \(\pmb x^S\) must be on thebudget line. Suppose \(\pmb x^S\inRed\) and \(\pmb x^S\neq\pmbx^0\) . Then \(U(\pmb x^S)\geq U(\pmbx^0)\) since \(\pmb x^0\inB(p_1^\prime, p_2,m^\prime)\). But for some \(\pmb z\in Blue\), \(U(\pmb z)>U(\pmb x^S)\) due tomonotonicity, and so \(U(\pmb z)>U(\pmbx^S)\geq U(\pmb x^0)\). Since \(\pmbz\in B(p_1,p_2,m)\), therefore \(\pmbx^0\in\pmb x^\prime(p_1,p_2,m)\) is impossible.

Theorem 2

If \(\pmb x^*(p_1,p_2,m)\) is uniquefor any fixed \(p_1,p_2,m\), then \(\pmb x^S\in Green\).

Proof

Suppose \(\pmb x^s\in Red\) and\(\pmb x^S\neq\pmb x^0\) . Since \(\pmb x^S\in B(p_1,p_2,m)\), where \(\pmb x^0=\pmb x^*(p_1,p_2,m)\) is theunique solution, \(U(\pmb x^0)>U(\pmbx^S)\). But then since \(\pmb x^0\inB(p_1^\prime,p_2,m^\prime)\), \(\pmbx^*(p_1^\prime,p_2,m^\prime)=\pmb x^S\) is impossible.

Theorem 3

There exists \(\pmb x^S\in\pmbx^*(p_1^\prime,p_2,m^\prime)\) such that \(\pmb x^S\in Green\).

Proof

If \(\pmb x^0\in\pmbx^*(p_1^\prime,p_2,m^\prime)\), we are done. Suppose \(\pmb x^0\not\in\pmbx^*(p_1^\prime,p_2,m^\prime)\), take any \(\pmb z\in\pmbx^*(p_1^\prime,p_2,m^\prime)\). Since \(U(\pmb z)>U(\pmb x^0)\), \(\pmb z\not\in Red\). So \(\pmb z\in Green\).

Revisiting Giffen

Large income effect can cancel substitution effect, resulting indecreasing price and consumption.

Theorem 4

Under monotonic preference / unique solutions (or both), 1. AGiffen good must be an inferior good.2. An inferior good need not be a Giffengood.

Other Decomposition

  • Hicksian Decomposition

Lecture 9 Endowment

Endowment

  • Consumer has utility function \(U(x_1,x_2,\cdots,x_n)\) andincome endowment \[(\omega_1,\cdots,\omega_n)\in X\]
  • Given prices \(\pmb p\), maximizesutility. \[\begin{cases}\max U(x_1,\cdots,x_n)\\s.t. &\pmb x\pmb p\leq m\\&x_1\geq 0,\cdots,x_n\geq 0\end{cases}\Rightarrow\begin{cases}\max U(x_1,\cdots,x_n)\\s.t. &\pmb x\pmb p\leq \pmb\omega\pmb p\\&x_1\geq 0,\cdots,x_n\geq 0\end{cases}\]

Cobb-Douglas

  • \(U(x_1,x_2)=x_1^ax_2^b,a,b>0\)
  • Start with income \(m\): \[\pmb x^*(\pmbp,m)=\left(\cfrac{a}{a+b}\cfrac{m}{p_1},\cfrac{b}{a+b}\cfrac{m}{p_2}\right)\]
  • Start with endowment \((\omega_1,\omega_2)\): \[\pmb x^*(\pmbp,\pmb\omega)=\left(\cfrac{a}{a+b}\cfrac{p_1\omega_1+p_2\omega_2}{p_1},\cfrac{b}{a+b}\cfrac{p_1\omega_1+p_2\omega_2}{p_2}\right)\]

What's more

  • Underlying assumption: No transaction cost

  • If gross demand 总需求 \(x_i^*>\omega_i\)

    • I want to consume more than I start with
    • \(x_i^*-\omega_i\) = Net demand净需求

  • If gross demand 总需求 \(x_i^*<\omega_i\)

    • I want to consume less than I start with
    • \(\omega_i-x_i^*\) = Net supply净供给

Budget Sets with Endowments

An illustration

  1. The consumer starts with goods \(\omega\inX\)
  2. Which defines the budget set with \(\pmbx\pmb p=\pmb\omega\pmb p\)
  3. And gives solution \(\pmb x^*(\pmbp,\pmb\omega\pmb p)\)
  4. If \(p_1\) decreases to \(p_1^\prime\), wealth decreases to \(\pmb\omega\pmb p^\prime\)
  5. The new budget set is defined by \(\pmbx\pmb p^\prime=\pmb\omega\pmb p^\prime\)
  6. New solution given by \(\pmb x^*(\pmbp^\prime,\pmb\omega\pmb p^\prime)\)

Price offer curve

Suppose \(p_1\) decreases to \(p_1^\prime\) \(p_1\) price offer curve as \(p_1\) decreases to \(p_1^\prime\)

Endowment Income Effect

Income and Wealth

  • Slutsky decomposition
    • Captures “changes in (real) income” when price changes
    • Even though nominal income \(m\)does not change.
  • With endowment,
    • When \(p_1\) changes, nominalincome \(\pmb\omega\pmbp=\omega_1p_1+\omega_2p_2\) also changes!
    • But the change (typically) does not capture all of real incomechanges
    • So, what is income effect?

Two benchmarks for income: - The money you need to buy originalbundle at new prices (Slutsky’s \(m^\prime\)) - Your original wealth, as ifyou sold everything and held cash before price change, i.e., \(\omega_1p_1+\omega_2p_2\)

Definitions

  1. \(\pmb x^0:=\pmb x^*(\pmb p,\pmb\omega\pmbp)\)
  2. \(\pmb x^1:=\pmb x^*(\pmbp^\prime,\pmb\omega\pmb p^\prime)\)
  3. Slutsky's intermediate bundle: \(\pmbx^S:=\pmb x^*(\pmb p^\prime,m^\prime)\) where \(m^\prime=\pmb x^0\pmb p^\prime\)
  4. NEW:\(\pmb x^E:=\pmb x^*(\pmbp^\prime,\pmb\omega\pmb p)\) "new prices with originalwealth"
  • Substitution effect: \(\pmb x^S-\pmbx^0\)
  • Ordinary income effect: \(\pmb x^E-\pmbx^S\)
  • Endowment income effect: \(\pmb x^1-\pmbx^E\)

Illustration

Together

Effects

Ordinary Income Effect

Well-behaved preferences & \(x_1\) is a normal good

Theorem 1

A decrease (resp. increase) in \(p_i\) leads to positive (resp. negative)ordinary income effect on \(x_i\).

Endowment Income Effect

Well-behaved preferences & \(x_1\) is a normal good

Theorem 2

A decrease (resp. increase) in \(p_i\) leads to negative (resp. positive)endowment income effect on \(x_i\).

Total income effect

Well-behaved preferences & \(x_1\) is a normal good

Theorem 3

Total income effect = \(x_1^1-x_1^S\geq0\) if and only if \(x_1^0\geq\omega_1\).

"\(p_i\) decreased, am I richer orpoorer?" - If I was a net demander 净需求者 of good \(i\), I am richer. - If I was a net supplier净供给者 of good \(i\), I ampoorer.

补充：如果是inferior good, 有可能净需求者收入效应为负再补充：inferior good不可能有净供给者

Combining Income andEndowment

\[\begin{align}&\max U(x_1,\cdots,x_n)\\s.t.&\pmb x\pmb p\leq\pmb\omega\pmb p+m\\&x_1\geq 0,\cdots,x_n\geq 0\end{align}\]

The labor supply problem

  • A worker starts with income 𝑚 and allocable hours \(\bar R\)
  • \(\bar R\) can be used for leisure\((R)\) or wage-earning labor \((\bar R-R)\).
  • There is one consumption good \(C\), with price \(p_C\) \[\begin{align}\max_{C,R}U(C,R)\\s.t. p_cC=w(\bar R-R)+m\end{align}\]

Backward bending laborsupply

entry.title: 红龙的誓言
entry.content:
《明日方舟》特别映像[维多利亚：红龙的誓言]

This is a story of Victoria, a tale from the distant past. 

这是很久很久以前的，维多利亚的故事

An era when Spring remained, an age before stone castles.

那时春天还没有离开大地，石头还没有垒成城堡

A time when a girl made friends with two crimson dragons.

小小的女孩与两条红龙成了朋友

One of them was greedy, but the other was true and brave.

一条红龙贪婪，另一条勇猛

Both swore for eternity to protect her beauty and grace.

他们都发誓，会永远守护在她身边

Everywhere they went, the girl would find and take

每当他们走到了新的一处，

the most beautiful flower growing in that place.

女孩就会去摘下那里最漂亮的花朵


Then one day came when the greedy one exclaimed,

直到有一天，贪婪的红龙向女孩开口：

"Grant me a gift, should you call yourself my friend."

“作为朋友，你为什么不送我一件礼物？”

With honeyed tongue it begged the girl to braid a wreath

他用花言巧语，想要换取一顶花环

with the flowers she had gathered, and the girl gladly agreed.  

他要将女孩一路上采下的花都编进其中，其中女孩则欣然答应

With deft hands she wove a beauteous floral garland,

女孩用她的巧手编好了美丽的花环，

and placed it around the head of the greedy red dragon.

为贪婪的红龙戴在了头顶。


Yet the dragon of courage said,

勇猛的红龙则说：

"No boon for me, no gift do I need,

“我要的不是礼物。

our journey is incomplete, and there's much for us to see."

我们的旅途还没有结束，前方还有许多风景。”

And thus, it departed alone and flew to the mountains beyond,

于是他独自离开，飞过了远方的群山。

where it created Tara, a kingdom to call its own.

在山的另一边，他建起了名为塔拉的王国。

The flowers that thrive here grow in no other land.

这里盛开的花，与其他任何地方都不同。

The domain was deemed perfect to adorn the girl's fine hand.

红龙想，自己会将独一无二的美景送到女孩的手中。


The wind told the greedy one of its kin's great findings.

风把这个消息带给了贪婪的红龙。

Speedily it flew towards Tara with the girl upon its wings.

他带着女孩，振翼飞向塔拉

And the greedy drake was awed, dazzled by the native bloom.

花朵的美艳摄人心魄，令他不住称赞

"Resplendent shall be our crown when we take that flower fromyou."

“只要有你这一朵花作为点缀，我的花冠就会熠熠生辉”

The good drake was speechless as greed pressed the demand.

面对这样贪婪的索求，勇猛的红龙无法答应。

There was nothing left of spring, but the blossom of its ownland.

对方已经将整个春天据为己有，而自己只有送给女孩的这一朵花了。


Long battled the dragons, a feud of naught but woe.

为此他们争执了很久，那场闹剧无比可悲

But greed emerged triumphant, the flower was then bestowed.

直到贪婪者得到了胜利，塔拉的花朵也被编进花环

Though the blossom suffered wounds and several petals were shed,

花朵已经残缺，几片花瓣被打落。

it became the brightest jewel upon the greedy dragon's head.

但在红龙的花冠上，它仍然是最夺目的明珠。

The girl secretly wept watching her friends fight and bleed.

女孩为自己朋友之间的争斗难过，却只能偷偷哭泣。

Then a lion snuck to her giving whispers that soothed her grief.

这时，一只狮子悄悄来到她身边，轻声细语让她不要担忧

And the lion told the girl that it had a very large pride,

狮子告诉女孩，他还有许多同族，

who would swear to protect her and vowed to stay by her side.

他们也会起誓保护她，陪伴在她身边。


So the girl forgot her sorrows and played with new-found friends,

与狮群作伴，让女孩忘记了伤心的事。

and no longer yearned for the drake who dwelt in distant lands.

生活在远方土地上的那条红龙，也不再令她挂念。

But the draken war barely ended when the lion pushed its claim.

但趁着两条红龙结束争执，狮子立刻露出獠牙

It seized the girl and roared, "Put the crown upon my mane!"

他挟持了女孩，高声咆哮着：“为我戴上那顶花冠！”

The good drake had not healed, but valiantly it challenged thethreat.

勇敢的红龙伤口还没有愈合，却依然挺身去对抗狮群的威胁

Not for the crown it fought and killed but the oath it swore tokept.

他不是为争夺花环而厮杀，只是不曾忘记自己最初立下的誓言。

But the pride was ready for war and spilled the dragon's blood.

他的鲜血流过的战场就是证词。

It drenched the fertile earth and turned it to barren mud.

塔拉原本丰饶的土地因此变得荒芜


The people grew cold and starved, now that winter has arrived.

现在冬天已经来临，这片土地上的人们忍受着饥饿与寒冷。

They remain cowed and silent, though a question lingered in mind.

他们不敢开口，却有一个问题始终萦绕在心间。

"Is it gone, our crimson dragon who lives beyond the peaks?

“我们的红龙是否还在？”

Is it gone, our virtuous guardian, the one with no greed?"

“那曾经君临顶点而无所贪图，誓守德行的红龙啊，它是否还在？”

Are you listening, Loughshinny?

拉芙希妮，你在听吗？

Can you...... and will you answer that question for us?

你们能够……你们会去回答那个问题吗？

entry.title: 数据库原理与系统-课程笔记
entry.content:
本笔记整理自安泰经济与管理学院2023年秋季学期课程MGTS3501-01数据库原理与系统，授课人是林学民老师。

：感觉课程笔记有点乱，回头自己整理

Lecture 1 Introduction

Database很有用

Data

known facts that can be recorded and have implicit meaning

Types of data

  • Unstructured
    • 乱搞
  • Structured
    • Stored with a rigid and strict schema
    • Can be organized into relational databases #### Database ManagementSystem (DBMS) A DBMS is software that allows applications to store andanalyze information in a database.
Contains
  • Collection of interrelated data
  • Set of programs to access the data (i.e., define, create, query,update, and administrate)
  • An environment that is both convenient andefficient to use
Features
  • Data independence
  • Efficient Data Access
  • Data Integrity and Security
  • Data Administration
  • Concurrent Access and Crash Recovery
  • Reduced Application Development Time

Database System

The database and DBMS together 好，解决下列问题 - Data redundancy andinconsistency - Difficulty in accessing data - Data isolation - multiplefiles and formats - Integrity problems - Atomicity of updates - Hard toallow concurrent access by multiple users

Lecture 2 ConceptualDatabase Design

Data Modeling: - conceptual - logical - physical

Entity-Relationship Model

Chen, 1976 - Entity: collection of attributesdescribing object of interest - Relationship:association between entities (objects) -Attribute(unofficially): data item describing aproperty of interest

Entity

"Entities represent things in the real world, andattributes describe properties of entities."

Entity type

An entity type defines a collection of entities thathave the same attributes.

  • An entity type describes the schema orintension for a set of entities that share the samestructure.
  • An entity type is represented in ER diagrams as a rectangular boxenclosing the entity type name.
  • The collection of entities of a particular entity type is groupedinto an entity set, which is also called theextension of the entity type.

Attributes

Simple vs Composite - Simple Attributes (orAtomic Attributes) are attributes that are notdivisible. - Composite attributes can be divided intosmaller subparts, which represent more basic attributes with independentmeanings. - 用simple还是用composite，看需求

Single-value vs multi-value - 字面意思

Derived vs stored - Derived: value is derivable fromanother attribute - 可以把derived attribute存成storedattribute，权衡update cost和query cost

Null Value

NULL values represent attributes whose values areunknown or do not exist for someentity instance. In general, it is a special value to indicate a lack ofvalue.

Key

Key constraint in ER Modeling: in any extension ofthe entity type, no two entities have the same values for their keyattribute or key attributes.

Super key

A super key is a set of one or more attributes thatuniquely identify any entity instance of an entity type.

Composite key

Keys containing multiple attributes are compositekeys.

Candidate key

Minimal super key (no subset is a key)

Primary key

A candidate key chosen by DB designer

Question

If an entity type has \(n\)attributes, - How many super keys can it have most? - \(2^n-1\) - How many candidate keys can ithave most? - \(n\choose \frac{n}{2}\)### Weak Entity A weak entity doesn't have any primary key but does havea partial key (discriminator). ：似乎，一对一的weakentity可以没有partial key

Partial key/discriminator

a key that is partially unique. i.e., only a subset of the attributescan be identified using it

A strong entity is an entity a regular entity wherethere is a primary key that uniquely identifies all instances.

Identifying relationship: the relationship typebetween a weak entity type to the owner of the weak entity type.

Relationship

  • Relationships relates one entity type to another entity type.
  • An entity type can be related to more than one other entities, andwill have a different role to play for each relationship (name eachrelationship to distinguish them).
  • An entity can also have different relationships with anotherentity.
  • Relationships can be illustrated using occurrence diagrams

Constraint

  • 1:1, N:M
  • Total Participation: each entity instance mustparticipate in at least one relationship instance.
  • Partial Participation: not necessarily total.

Attributes

  • Relationship has attributes too

超类和子类

  • 单线vs双线
  • d（子类不相交）vs o（子类有交集）

More on Relationships

  • Binary relationship: relationship of degree 2
  • Degree (of a relationship): number of participatingentity types.
  • 多元关系，一般是多对多对多，但是也不一定

ER-Diagram

Notations

Example

Lecture 3 Relational DataModel

Edgar F.Codd, 1970

Structure

In the relational model, everything is described using relations. Arelation can be thought of as a named table. - column:attribute - row: tuple -unordered as set: expresses membership - allowed valuesfor an attribute: domain - Composite and multivaluedattributes are not allowed!

Why relational model?

  • Very simple model
  • Often a good match for the way we think about our data
  • Foundations in logic and set theory

Keys

Same as key in ER-model - super key - candidatekey - primary key - designated candidate key - Foreign key - anattribute that keeps the value of a primary key of another relation.

Relational IntegrityConstraints

To keep relational database valid:

Key constraint

candidate key values must be unique for every relation instance.

Entity integrity

an attribute that is part of a primary key cannot be NULL.

Referential integrity

The value of foreign key must occur in the other relation or beentirely NULL.

Insertion

When inserting, we need to check - that the candidate keys are notalready present, - that the value of each foreign key either  - is allNULL, or - is all non-NULL and occurs in the referenced relation.

Deletion

When deleting, we need to check referentialintegrity - check whether the primary key occurs in anotherrelation.

ER to Relational Data ModelMapping

7 steps

注意事项

  • derived attribute 不用画在RDM中
  • 关系存在n：m的就要重新画表，只有关系中全为1：1或1：n不用重新画表
    • 要重新画表的例如: 1:n:m, n:m:q, ...

Step 1 Mapping Strong EntityTypes

For each strong entity (not weak entity) type E,create a new relation R with - Attributes: - all simple attributes (andsimple components of composite attributes) of E. - Key: - key of E asthe primary key for the relation.

强实体，正常搞 - Attributes：正常搞，复合的就拆开来 -Key：该强实体的Key

Employee

SSNFnameLnameBirdate

Department

NameLocation

Project

PnumberPname

Step 2 Mapping Weak EntityTypes

For each weak entity type W with the owner entitytype E, create a new relation R with - Attributes: - all simpleattributes (and simple components of composite attributes) of W, - andinclude the primary key attributes of the relation derived from E as theforeign key. - Key of R: - foreign key to E and partial key of W.

弱实体，也正常搞，加上依赖实体的key -Attributes：正常搞，加上依赖的实体的primary key，作为foreign key -Key：Foreign key+partial key

Dependent

SSNFname BirdateRelation

：上面SSN和Fname下划线是连一起的，作为一整个新的key

Step 3 Mapping 1:1Relationship Types

For each 1:1 relationship type B. Let E and F be theparticipating entity types. Let S and T be the corresponding relations.- Choose one of S and T (let S be the one that participates totally ifthere is one). - Add attributes from the primary key of T to S as aforeign key. - Add all simple attributes (and simple components ofcomposite attributes) of B as attributes of S.

：有三种添加方式，copy A to B, copy B to A, Combine A and B intoC

1对1关系，两种方式，只要copy，不要combine -Attributes：正常搞，加上发生关系的实体的key 作为attribute -Key：一个primary key+foreign key（不用下划线）

：如果totalparticipation的话，把不total的add到total的table中去，好使

Manager

NameLocationMSSNMdate

Step 4 Mapping 1:NRelationship Types

For each 1:N relationship type B. Let E and F be theparticipating entity types. Let S and T be the corresponding relations.Let E be the entity on the 1 side and F on the N side.

Add to the relation belonging to entity T, - the attributes from theprimary key of S as a foreign key - any simple attributes (or simplecomponents of composite attributes) from relationship B.

1对n关系，把1的key copy到n的table中去，只copy不combine -Attributes：n的table+1的foreign key - Key：n的key

Works_For

SSNBirdateFnameLnameDname

Step 5 Mapping M:NRelationship Types

For each N:M relationship type B. Let E and F be theparticipating entity types. Let S and T be the correspondingrelations

Create a new relation R (cross-reference) with attributes : -Attributes from the key of S as foreign key, and attributes from the keyof T as foreign key, and simple attributes, and simple components ofcomposite attributes of relation B. - Key : All attributes from the keyof S and the key of T.

m对n关系，乖乖重新搞 - Attributes：m和n的primary key+正常搞 -Key：m和n的primary key组合在一起成为key

Participation

PnumberESSNTime

Step 6 MappingMultivalued Attributes

For each multivalued attribute A, where A is an attribute of E,create a new relation R. - If A is a multivalued simple attribute, -Attributes of R = Simple attribute A, and key of E as a foreign key. -If A is a multivalued composite attribute, - Attributes of R = Allsimple components of A, and key of E as a foreign key. In both cases,the primary key of R is the set of all attributes in R.

Multivalued Attribute，加上所属的Entity -Attributes：Attribute本身+Entity的key - Key：所有Simpleattribute+Entity的key组合

Step 7 Mapping N-aryRelationship Types

和Step 5差不多

ER vs Relational Model

ER ModelRelational Model
Entity TypeEntity relation
1:1 or 1:N relationship typeForeign key (or relationship relation)
M:N relationship typeRelationship relation and two foreign key
n-ary relationship typeRelationship relation and n foreign key
Simple AttributeAttribute
Composite AttributeSet of simple component attributes
Multivalued AttributeRelation and foreign key

Lecture 4 Relational Algebra

E.F.Codd(1970)

  • Relational Algebra is a procedural data manipulation language(DML).It specifies operations on relations to define new relations:
    • Unary Relational Operations
      • Select, Project
    • Operations from Set Theory
      • Union, Intersection, Difference, Cartesian Product
    • Binary Relational Operations
      • Join, Divide.

Select

The SELECT operation/predicate is used to select a subset of thetuples of a relation R, satisfying some condition. \[\sigma_{<selection\ condition>}(R)\]- 横切片

Selection Condition

  • <attribute> operator <constant>

  • <attribute> operator <attribute> Whereoperator is one of \(=, <, \leq,>, \geq, \neq,\cdots\)

  • <expression> operator <expression> Withthis, we can use Boolean connectives AND, OR, NOT as operator :\(\land,\lor,\lnot\)

Properties of Selection

  • Consecutive selects can be combined
    • \(\sigma_{<cond1>}(\sigma_{<cond2>}(R))\)
  • Selection is a commutative operation
    • \(\sigma_{<cond1>}(\sigma_{<cond2>}(R))\) isthe same as \(\sigma_{<cond2>}(\sigma_{<cond1>}(R))\)

Project

The PROJECT operation is used to project a subset of the attributes(column) of a relation. \[\pi_{<attribute\list>}(R)\] - 纵切片 - Result: - schema: attribute list \((A_1,\cdots,A_k)\) - instance: the set ofall subtuples \(t[A_1,\cdots,A_k]\)where \(t\in R\)

Duplicates

Duplicate elimination:project会去重，结果中的tuple不可能有重复的内容

Properties of Project

  • Consider \(\pi_{<list1>}(\pi_{<list2>}(R))\)
    • If <list2> contains all the attributes in<list1>:  
    • Then \(\pi_{<list1>}(\pi_{<list2>})(R))=\pi_{<list1>}(R)\)
    • Else the operation is not well defined.

Set Union

UNION is the set theoretic union of the tuples of two relations.\[ R\cup S=\{t:t\in R\ or\ t\in S\}\]- R and S must be union compatible! - Unioncompatibility: there is a 1-1 correspondence between their attributes:the same name and the same domain

Set Intersection

INTERSECTION is an operation that includes all tuples that are inpresent both relations. \[R\cap S=\{t:t\in R\and\ t\in S\}\] - R and S must also be unioncompatible!

Set Difference

DIFFERENCE is a relation that includes all tuples that are in theleft relation but not in the right relation \[R-S=\{t:t\in R\ and\ t\not\in S\}\] - Rand S must be union compatible!

Summary

Cartesian Product

\[R\times S=\{t_1||t_2:t_1\in R\ and\ t_2\in S\}\] - R and S not required to be union compatible - Thenumber of tuples in the output relation is always \(|R|*|S|\) -一般假设R和S的attributes不交。若非如此，要区分开来

Example

Join (\(\theta\)-join)

JOIN is used to combine related tuples from two relations into single"longer" tuples. \[R\bowtie_{<join\condition>}S=\{t_1||t_2:t_1\in R\ and\ t_2\in S\ and\ <join\condition>\}\]

  • 如果两个join的对象没有相对应的attribute，怎么办？
    • 做Cartesian product

Equi-join

A type of theta-join where the only comparison operator used is “=”is called an Equi-join

Example

\[ENROLMENT\bowtie_{(Superviser=Person\#)}RESEARCHER\]

等价表示

\[\pi_{\{E'ment\#,S'ee,S'or,Name,D'ment,Degree\}}(\sigma_{(Supervisor=Person\#)}(ENROLMENT\timesRESEARCHER))\]

Natural join

理解为把两个table按照某attribute对应，然后join到一起 -某attribute可以是多attribute

Intuitions: - Enforce equality on all attributes with same name -Eliminate one copy of duplicated attributes

Divide

Return all tuples from relation R which are associated to every S’stuple. \[\div\]

等价表示

\[R\div S\Leftrightarrow\begin{cases}TEMP1&\leftarrow\pi_{R-S}(R)\\TEMP2&\leftarrow\pi_{R-S}((TEMP1\times S)-\pi_{R-S,S}(R))\\RESULT&=TEMP1-TEMP2\end{cases}\]

Rename

\[\rho_{<new\ name>}(R)\]

Basic vs Extended Operators

Basic operators

\[\{\sigma,\pi,\cup,-,\times(,\rho)\}\]

Extended operators

Join, intersection, divide

Aggregate Operators

We can use an aggregation operator \(\gamma\) and an function such as SUM, AVG,MIN, MAX, or COUNT.

超级 Summary

OPERATIONPURPOSENOTATION
SELECTSelects all tuples that satisfy the selection condition from arelation R\(\sigma_{<selection\condition>}(R)\)
PROJECTProduces a new relation with only some of the attributes of R andremoves duplicate tuples.\(\pi_{<attribute\list>}(R)\)
THETA-JOINProduces all combinations of tuples from R and S that satisfy thejoin condition.\(R\bowtie_{<join\condition>}S\)
EQUI-JOINProduces all the combinations of tuples from R and S that satisfy ajoin condition with only equality comparisons.\(R\bowtie_{<join\condition>}S\)
NATURAL-JOINSame as EQUIJOIN except that the join attributes of S are notincluded in the resulting relation; if the join attributes have the samenames, they do not have to be specified at all.\(R\bowtie_{<join\condition>}S\)
UNIONProduces a relation that includes all the tuples in R or S or both Rand S; R and S must be union compatible.\(R\cup S\)
INTERSECTIONProduces a relation that includes all the tuples in both R and S; Rand S must be union compatible.\(R\cap S\)
DIFFERENCEProduces a relation that includes all the tuples in R that are notin S; R and S must be union compatible.\(R-S\)
CARTESIAN PRODUCTProduces a relation that has the attributes of R and S and includesas tuples all possible combinations of tuples from R and S.\(R\times S\)
DIVISIONProduces a relation T(X) that includes all tuples t[X] in R(Z) thatappear in R in combination with every tuple from S(Y), where Z=X\(\cup\)Y.\(R(Z)\div S(Y)\)

Lecture 5 SQL

  • SQL = Structured Query Language (pronounced“sequel”).
  • Developed at IBM (San Jose Lab) during the 1970’s, and standardisedduring the 1980’s.
  • A standard language for querying and manipulatingrelational DBMSs.
  • Interactive via GUI or command line or embedded in programs.
  • Declarative, based on relational algebra.

乱七八糟的东西

SQL Identifiers

Identifiers in SQL use similar conventions to common programminglanguages: - a sequence of alpha-numerics, startingwith an alphabetic, - not case-sensitive, - reserveword disallowed - Whether you can use sign (@), dollarsign ($), number sign (#), or underscore (_) depends on thestandard.

SQL Keywords

https://www.postgresql.org/docs/current/sql-keywords-appendix.html

例如 - ALTER AND CREATE - FROM INSERT NOT OR - SELECT TABLE WHERE

SQL Data Types

  • The NULL value is a member of all data types.
    • Comparison against NULL yields FALSE.
    • 用IS NULL或IS NOT NULL判断
Numeric

Integers - smallint (2 byte integer) - int (4 byte integer) - bigint(8 byte integer)

Real numbers - real - double - numeric(<precision>,<scale>) - <precision>: specifysignificant digits in the whole number - <scale>: specify digitsafter the decimal point

String
String Literal

A string literal is a sequence of zero or more characters - casesensitive: 'John'!='JOHN'

  • CHAR(n)
    • n length, left-justified blank-padded
  • VARCHAR(n)
    • can be between 0 and n length, no padding
String Operators
  • string || string … concatenate two strings
  • LENGTH (string) ... return length of string
  • SUBSTR (string, start, length) ... extract chars from withinstring

Example: - 'Post'|| 'greSQL' \(\rightarrow\) 'PostgreSQL' -substring('Thomas' from 2 for 3) \(\rightarrow\) 'hom'

SQL Like Operator

匹配正则表达式（？）

Two kinds of string pattern-matching - The symbol _ (underscore)matches any single characters - The symbol % (percent) matches zero ormore characters

  • Practice
    • String LIKE 'Ja%'
      • Strings beginning with 'Ja'
    • String LIKE  '_i%'
      • Strings with 'i' as 2nd letter
    • String LIKE '%o%o%'
      • Strings contains two ‘o’s
SQL Dates

Format is typically DD-Mon-YYYY, e.g., ''18-Aug-1998' Accepts otherformats

Comparison operators implement before (<) and after (>).

(start1, end1) OVERLAPS (start2, end2) - This expression yields truewhen two time periods (defined by their endpoints) overlap, false whenthey do not overlap. - SELECT (DATE '2001-02-16', DATE '2001-12-21')OVERLAPS (DATE '2001-10-30', DATE '2002-10-30') - Result: true

Basic SELECT Structure

SELECT<Attribute list> FROM<Table list>WHERE<Condition>

  • <attribute list>: list of attributes
  • <table list>: list of relations
  • <condition>: list of conditions (Boolean expression)

Formal semantics (relational algebra): - start with relation R inFROM clause - apply \(\sigma\) usingCondition in WHERE clause - apply \(\pi\) using Attributes in SELECT clause

NULL in SQL

null value = unknown

重点！：Result of where clause predicate is treated asFALSE if it evaluates as unknown

Comparisons with null returns unknown - Example: 5 < null, null<> null, null = null

Three-valued logic using the truth value unknown - OR - (unknown ortrue)   = true - (unknown or false)  = unknown        - (unknown orunknown) = unknown

  • AND
    • (true and unknown)  = unknown
    • (false and unknown) = false
    • (unknown and unknown) = unknown
  • NOT
    • (not unknown) = unknown

-重点特例！： "P is unknown" evaluates to true if predicate Pevaluates as unknown
